profiles: Summary I emphasize in user interface, interaction design, and user experience and have worked for large corporations and successful startups. Prior to arriving in the Bay Area I spent seven years at the Rhode Island School of Design where I received an undergraduate degree in Industrial Design and a master's degree in Graphic Design. In my free time I enjoy collecting wood type and making colorful things by hand. Summary I care deeply about designing for meaningful outcomes. Not all problems are created equal so it’s important we identify opportunities that produce value for our customers. Through research and analysis, explorations and experiments I help businesses build things that matter. 
 
At a Glance 
• I practice user-centered design and I am a product management geek. 
• I help teams think through complex problems and build alignment toward common goals. 
• My design process is forever evolving as I learn new things and work within new environments. 
• I lean on years of personal expertise and user research to ask beautiful questions. 
• I lead design conversations through sketches, mock-ups, user flows, wireframes and prototypes. 
• I'm a user experience designer amused by human behavior and how it informs behavioral design. 
 
Areas of Interest 
• User-centered Design 
• Interaction Design 
• Behavioral Design 
• Visual Design 
• Information Architecture 
• UX Strategy 
• User Testing and Analysis 
• Agile / Lean Methodologies 
• Product Strategy 
• Product Management

Summary I’m a seasoned user experience and interaction designer with hands-on experience in working closely with some of the largest international, US and Australian brands on high profile projects.  
 
I have a strong background in design for multi-platform and emerging technologies, such as mobile, tablets, connected TV and inflight entertainment. I am passionate about the intersect of the physical and the digital, the relationship between hardware and software, and I love exploring the extension of experience design beyond the interface. 
 
I am a natural leader with strong stakeholder management skills with creative flair and a keen eye for balancing innovation and business strategy with real user needs.

August 2015  – Present (1 month) Vancouver, Canada Area Senior UX Designer Google November 2014  –  June 2015  (8 months) Mountain View, CA During this time, I worked on Human-Machine Interaction Design (HMI) on the Google Robotics team. 
 
Collaborating closely with a small team of Roboticists and Engineers, I helped design magical and novel ways to interact meaningfully with Robots. UX Designer III Google October 2013  –  November 2014  (1 year 2 months) Mountain View, CA During my first year at Google, I worked on the Identity and Authentication team, leading the user experience design for complex, cross-product projects with a very high impact and visibility on Google and Google's user base. In addition to launching a redesign of the Android Sign In/Sign Up flow, I helped empower the Identity design team by improving their design process, collaboration skills, and helping mentor team members. Senior Interaction Designer frog January 2013  –  September 2013  (9 months) San Francisco Bay Area As a Senior Interaction Designer at frog, I worked in small teams of amazing designers and strategists to deliver magical and effective solutions for our clients. I focused on building strong, trusted working relationships with our clients through inclusive workshops, and tight feedback loops, resulting in some amazing outcomes for projects such as: 
- a future vision for a flagship mobile product for a major OEM 
- A complete site redesign and long term business strategy for a beloved brand Yellow Pages, alongside their digital rebrand to YP.com  
- product positioning strategy and user experience vision concepts for Verizon Communications & Messaging across multiple platforms, focusing on mobile 
 
Clients included: 
A major OEM, Verizon, Westfield, Yellow Pages (YP.COM) Senior Interaction Designer frog April 2012  –  October 2012  (7 months) Sydney Area, Australia I led the user experience design for several high profile projects during frog’s long-term engagement with Telstra - a major telecommunications company in Australia. Working on-site with Telstra, we helped reimagine the online shopping experience for Telstra’s diverse range of phone, mobile, internet, and television products and services. Integrating closely with their internal development teams, I helped instill and foster a strong Agile development culture at Telstra that included design thinking in the process. Principal UX Architect Massive Interactive July 2011  –  February 2012  (8 months) Sydney, Australia I led the UX team in Sydney to drive innovative and effective solutions for our clients. I was involved closely up-front with client and stakeholder management, strategy and concept design. For key projects, I worked end to end whilst delegating tasks and overseeing a large range of other projects across the team. I closely mentored and outlined professional development plans for UX team members to ensure our process was constantly growing and evolving to suit the ever-changing design problem space. In addition, I was involved in creative pitches for new business, most of which were successful in winning high profile work, such as with the BBC. 
 
Speaking: 
Co-presented "Shaping the future of BBC News for the connected Home" at UX Australia 2011 
Presented "The Upside of Stakeholder Involvement (10 min talk)" at UX Australia 2011 
 
Clients included: 
Emirates, Panasonic Avionics, Iberia, Telstra, TAB Senior UX Architect Massive Interactive July 2009  –  July 2011  (2 years 1 month) Sydney, Australia During my time as a Senior UX Architect, I was the UX lead for many key projects, running the project end to end from discover, concept through to detailed specifications. In particular, the strength of the work produced and strong client relationships built with Telstra led to many further project opportunities for Massive. As a senior, I took on the responsibility of mentoring, training and often overseeing the work of UX team members. 
 
Highlight Projects: 
- Telstra T-Box 
- Sky NZ Online Media Platform 
 
Clients included:

We refined the visual language used to present multi-faceted information on the map, and also defined the typography, colors, iconography, and line elements to reflect the needs of both local and international users IF communication Design Award 2005 - Website for MaLiLian Furniture IF Design Germany September 2005 http://exhibition.ifdesign.de/entrydetails_en.html?beitrag_id=21439 
 
Objective: MaLiLian one-off furniture is positioned as “Art for Living” and caters to a global cosmopolitan clientele. Therefore, the company’s “catalogue” is web-based and needs to visualize the products in a very upscale fashion. In addition, exhibitions and events shall be published. Result: www.malilian.com provides a fully functional communications channel between MaLiLian, professional partners e.g. architects, media and customers. At the same time the site provides the emotional backdrop for the product philosophy. www.malilian.com has delivered a strong interest in the furniture pieces resulting in numerous sales. Design: MaLiLian’s expressive design asked for a sophisticated and very reduced graphic design. Playful exploration: One of the key features of the site is the user’s easy and playful navigation in discovering the furniture objects. The site mirrors the quest for interaction posed by MaLiLian objects in real life. The user is able to discover them via different avenues such as the themes defined by surfaces and materials as well as by the shapes and functions of the furniture pieces. At the same time such path of discovery can be changed at any time of the exploration. IF Design Award 2006 - Siemens Home Entertainment System IF Design Germany September 2006 http://exhibition.ifdesign.de/entrydetails_de?beitrag_id=27526 
 
Die gesamte Bedienung der Siemens Home Entertainment Dienste erfolgt durch Menüs und Bedienelemente auf dem Fernsehschirm, die mit Hilfe einer Fernbedienung gesteuert werden. Diese eingeschränkte Interaktionsweise erfordert es, bei der Gestaltung der Screenlayouts in hohem Maße auf Benutzerfreundlichkeit und Bedienkomfort zu achten. Typografie und Farbdesign wurden hinsichtlich Lesbarkeit auf dem Fernsehschirm optimiert. Die systematische Anwendung von Farbkombinationen und -kontrasten unterstützt eine klare Trennung zwischen den Bedien- und Anzeigeelementen und den vielschichtigen Informationen.
